column4: anyone know how to make mount -t cifs use netbios name resolution instead of dns?
you have a DNS server on this network ??
i dont have a dns server, but it seems to be resolving the name to some random computer somewhere on the internet rather than using netbios name resolution

you might need samba to use wins resolution; during the samba install it will ask you questions about using wins server etc. Whether linux can actually broadcast for a netbios resolution I dont know - I just use IP addresses
also, if your hostname is responding to a computer on the internet you must be adding some kind of dns suffix automatically in your networking - you could try remove that

doesn't that require actually having a wins server on the network? also, smbclient does broadcast for netbios resolution (once i changes smb.conf to say name resolve order = lmhosts bcast host wins); if smbclient can do it shouldn't cifs be able to as well?
thats what I am not sure about, I know samba can use wins... I dont know about cifs
any windows server on your network (master browser) could act as a wins server
having a wins server wasn't necessary with windows; anyway, how do i check for/remove a dns suffix? (right now the xp machine im trying to connect to is just called "quark")

in a workgroup environment the windows boxses elect a master browser - this server keeps track of who is who, its not a wins server like it is in a domain enivonment but there is a degree of netbios/wins resolution
have you given your ubuntu server a FQDN? such as box.somewhere.com or just a hostname such as box ?
both the ubuntu machine and the windows machine im trying to connect to just have hostnames (like box)
and when you ping quark from the terminal is it resolving to to quark.something ? what IP address are you getting back?
why not just use IP addresses by the way ?
ping quark tries to ping 8.15.7.117; not sure what that ip is or where its coming up with it
the ip changes depending on what network im on, which interface the other computer is using
